awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Towards Secure Networked Cyber-Physical Systems: A Theoretic Framework with Bounded Rationality
awd_abstract_narration:
Securing critical networked cyber-physical systems (NCPSs) such as the power grid or transportation systems has emerged as a major national and global priority. The networked nature of such systems renders them vulnerable to a range of attacks both in cyber and physical domains as corroborated by recent threats such as the Stuxnet worm. Developing security mechanisms for such NCPSs significantly differs from traditional networked systems due to interdependence between cyber and physical subsystems (with attacks originating from either subsystem), possible cooperation between attackers or defenders, and the presence of human decision makers in the loop. The main goal of this research is to develop the necessary science and engineering tools for designing NCPS security solutions that are applicable to a broad range of application domains. 

This project will develop a multidisciplinary framework that weaves together principles from cybersecurity, control theory, networking and criminology. The framework will include novel security mechanisms for NCPSs founded on solid control-theoretic and related notions, analytical tools that allow incorporation of bounded human rationality in NCPS security, and experiments with real-world attack scenarios. A newly built cross-institutional NCPS simulator will be used to evaluate the proposed mechanisms in realistic environments. This research transcends specific cyber-physical systems domains and provides the necessary tools to building secure and trustworthy NCPSs. The broader impacts include a new infrastructure for NCPS research and education, training of students, new courses, and outreach events focused on under-represented student groups.

por.por_cntn:
Securing critical and large-scale networked cyber-physical systems (NCPSs) such as the power grid, drone systems, or transportation systems has emerged as a major national and global priority. In this research, the intellectual merits include novel scientific foundations that can be used to identify vulnerability in NCPSs and develop threat mitigation and defense strategies that take into account the synergies across the cyber and physical functionalities of NCPSs. The developed frameworks and algorithms are grounded in rigorous mathematical foundations from game theory, learning, and optimization, and, thus, they provide provably secure solutions for NCPSs. In particular, by merging together ideas from game theory, psychology, and behavioral modeling, new secure protocols for NCPSs were developed while explicitly taking into account the presence of human actors, as defenders, administers, or hackers. The ensuing results showcases the impact of human decision making on NCPS security and provided new guidelines on how to secure a plethora of NCPSs that include the smart grid and autonomous NCPSs. The theoretical results were coupled with cross-institutional experimental evaluations that particularly targeted the NCPS security of the smart grid. The developed solutions can help protect a plethora of real-world critical infrastructure and, thus, they have far-reaching societal impact on current and future infrastructure. The foundational nature of the research led to broad impacts across multiple disciplines ranging from CPS to game theory, security, optimization, learning, smart grids, drone systems, and NCPS experimentation. The broader impacts included the design of new courses at Virginia Tech that shed light on the security of NCPS as well as an involvement of undergraduate and graduate students in wireless and social networking research. Outreach events targeted at under-represented female groups were conducted and involvement of students from a community college in Virginia was done via a science fair competition. Broad dissemination of the results was done using tutorials, workshops, keynotes, seminars, and online tools.
